original_data.question: A 52-year-old man with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dysuria and urinary urgency. He had been treated for urinary tract infections twice in the past 6 months. He is currently taking infliximab. Cystoscopy shows pearl-like plaques on the bladder wall. Biopsy of these lesions shows a focal layer of stratified squamous epithelium with hyperkeratosis. If the patient's bladder finding is caused by a vitamin deficiency, which of the following features is also most likely to be seen?

model_response:
The patient has cicatricial pemphigoid, a rare autoimmune blistering disease that most often affects the eyes and oral mucosa. The bladder lesions are due to a side effect of the medication infliximab. The medication blocks tumor necrosis factor (TNF), which results in the loss of the normal TNF-mediated suppression of squamous epithelial growth in the bladder. The result is the development of squamous metaplasia and subsequent carcinoma in situ and invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The other choices are not features of vitamin A deficiency.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

A chronic transmural inflammation that may involve any part of the DIGESTIVE TRACT from MOUTH to ANUS, mostly found in the ILEUM, the CECUM, and the COLON. In Crohn disease, the inflammation, extending through the intestinal wall from the MUCOSA to the serosa, is characteristically asymmetric and segmental. Epithelioid GRANULOMAS may be seen in some patients.
Record and study of past events.
Painful URINATION. It is often associated with infections of the lower URINARY TRACT.
An acute and compelling urge to urinate.
Subject to a process with the aim of readying for some purpose, improving, or remedying a condition.
Inflammatory responses of the epithelium of the URINARY TRACT to microbial invasions. They are often bacterial infections with associated BACTERIURIA and PYURIA.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A chimeric monoclonal antibody to TNF-ALPHA that is used in the treatment of RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS; ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS; PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS and CROHN'S DISEASE.
Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the urinary bladder.
The tissue layers that form the urinary bladder. They include the mucosa, submucosa, smooth muscle, and serosa.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

Epithelium consisting of multiple layers of cells that are flattened and more cuboidal toward the base. Its function is protection. Outer layers may be dead and hardened (keratinized) such as with skin or on top of wet, mucous surfaces such as the cornea
Any horny growth such as a wart or callus.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A condition due to a deficiency of one or more essential vitamins. (Dorland, 27th ed)
Discrete protein structural units that may fold independently of the rest of the protein and have their own functions.
